docs.text: david mamet has long been my favorite screenwriter and director .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: with his distinctive , more often than not ingenious dialogue , and his laid back style of direction nearly all of his movies are absolutely irresistible .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: some of them tend to be thickly layered , deceptive productions that require the audience to look at the film in a less superficial manner than the plot seems to require in order to discern its concealed message , or sometimes even a concealed storyline .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: and although the real plot in his new project the winslow boy is slightly more conspicuous than in some of his other endeavors , it is still a brilliantly complex , consistently riveting motion picture about honor , about sacrifice , and about the difference between what is commonly known as justice and what is right .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: oh , and it's rated g .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: incidentally , this is the first time that mamet has decided to adapt someone else's work ; namely a play by terrence rattigan , set in the 19th century .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he casts nigel hawthorne in the lead role as arthur winslow , a rich , aging man who finds out that his 14 year old son ronnie has been kicked out of the naval academy for allegedly stealing a 5 shilling postal note .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " did you do it ? " he asks his boy .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " no father , i didn't , " ronnie answers .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that's enough for arthur , who , with his oldest daughter ( rebecca pidgeon ) , immediately starts a crusade to bring his son's case to court .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: they enlist the help of sir robert morton , a notorious attorney to help them achieve that formidably daunting task .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it all seems fairly frivolous , and no matter how you look at it , the winslow case is not the trial of the century .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but arthur is determined to keep his family's word clean and he is willing to go quite far to make sure of that .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: soon enough , sir robert morton along with the rest of the country becomes equally wrapped up in the proceedings .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: so do we .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: all david mamet does for the script is tighten and hone the dialogue , but his style is still fairly apparent .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the characters still talk in his trademark staccatto lines and there is still tension present in conversations that no ordinary writer would be able to make tense .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but this is not mamet's norm , and it's refreshing to see mamet deviate from his world of crooks , gangsters as con men , wonderful as those films were .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: nigel hawthorne's performance is nearly flawless .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his delivery is that of a dignified yet not pompous man who seems to be getting beaten at his own game .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: we pity the man , but we also like him .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: rebecca pidgeon , david mamet's wife , who gave a fairly awful performance in the spanish prisoner is at the top of her game here as arthur's oldest daughter , a flailing feminist who gives her all to the winslow case as a way for making up for her lack of success in the women's suffrage movement .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the winslow boy is a wonderful movie that avoids cliches such as a seemingly inevitable courtroom scene and shoots higher -- it wants to make a real impact rather than a phony one .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: be honest : did you feel anything profound at or after the courtroom scenes in films like a time to kill ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if you wanted to but didn't , this is a movie for you .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is the epitome of subtlety : it's powerful without being too emotional , sad without even trying to be depressing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: david mamet can churn out some great scripts , but in this movie he proves to those who ever doubted it once and for all that he is a hell of a director too .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is almost a national treasure .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his films deserve their own genre .
docs.label: positive
